request_pathways.name: Duke Health Enterprise Authorization for Release of Information (M3132)
Mail to Duke University Hospital HIM, DUMC Box 3016, Durham, NC 27710

forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (image-only scan, superseded revision)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients use a single generic Authorization for Release of Information form (M3132) that serves both patient self-requests and third-party releases, with a 'Self' checkbox in the recipient section.

red_flags: Collects last 4 digits of SSN, which is not required by HIPAA for patient identification
Requires affirmative opt-in checkboxes for Mental/Behavioral Health and Genetic Testing records even for patient self-access, potentially restricting access to the complete designated record set
HIV/AIDS mentioned in disclosure text but no corresponding opt-in checkbox, creating ambiguity about release of those records
bright_spots: 67 fillable interactive fields enabling full on-screen completion without printing
Companion 3-page instruction document with plain-language definitions of each medical record type
Multiple electronic delivery options: MyChart patient portal, encrypted email, fax
Sensible defaults transparently stated on the form (2-year treatment window, abstract/summary for provider requests)
Email submission accepted alongside fax and mail — three non-in-person submission channels
Spanish-language version available on the official forms page

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available with minimal effort — forms are 2 clicks from the homepage on a well-organized medical records page with clearly labeled downloads.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital workflow — form-4 has 67 fillable fields for full on-screen completion, but submission requires emailing or faxing the completed PDF rather than a fully integrated online submission.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized six-part structure with clear section headers, inline guidance, and sensible defaults; minor issues include single-page density and unnamed fillable fields for accessibility.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the generic authorization form via the 'Self' checkbox and 'Personal' purpose, but the form wasn't designed for patient self-access — patients must navigate sections intended for third-party releases and the form does not reference Right of Access.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities — vague fee disclosure ('may charge a fee' without amounts), SSN collection not required by HIPAA, and sensitive-information opt-in may exceed what's needed for patient access — but nothing that would materially impede a patient.

overall.summary: Duke University Hospital provides a well-organized, technically competent records request experience with a strong fillable PDF and excellent companion documentation, held back from a top grade by its reliance on a generic authorization form rather than a dedicated patient access pathway.
